answers.author: Tom Nosack
answers.text:
We just put our fleet annual performance snapshot on line for this year, and it might be helpful as a jumping off point. Been doing them for about six years, most areas of the City are covered.
VERY low tech, made to tell the story at a glance. certainly not the most beautiful things, but the contents seem to hit a sweet spot regularly with the public. We also include measures for areas such as water, sewer and surface water, urban forestry finance, HR and more, about 30 areas.  We aim for a combination of workload and one or two of the others (cost, quality efficiency, or effectiveness) to tell a more complete story. Far from perfect, but useful for discussions and as a starting point the public seems to appreciate.
Here they are:  http://www.cityofvancouver.us/performance.asp?menuid=10462&submenuID=17767&itemID=17770 
or go to www.cityofvancouver.us/performance and choose "performance snapshots" from the left margin menu

answers.author: Gerald Young
answers.text:
Mike,
There's certainly a range of approaches on fleet and facilities.  Some jurisdictions focus on cost efficiency (per mechanic or custodian, per square foot, per vehicle, per mile, etc.).  Others look at minimizing repair/cleaning costs (e.g., through vehicle replacement criteria, preventive maintenance, choices of construction materials).  Regardless, ICMA recommends that such measures be supplemented by consideration of customer satisfaction, both on the quality and timeliness of service.
For some concrete examples of how jurisdictions are reporting their performance data, you can click  http://icma.org/en/results/center_for_performance_measurement/services_and_publications/certificate_program and review the "Public Reporting" links at the bottom of the page.
